title: Have we ever observed a Galaxy that we see today move beyond the observable universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, we haven’t and no we won’t. First of all, our civilization has only been around for at most a few ten thousand years. Telescopes have only been invented a few centuries ago. The recognition that “spiral nebulae” are, in fact, “island universes”, the term used back in the 1920s to describe galaxies outside our own Milky Way galaxy, is less than a century old. In contrast, the expansion of the universe takes place on a timescale of billions, tens of billions of years. Millions of times longer than the age of our human civilization. But suppose we somehow manage to stick around for many billions of years. Would we see a galaxy vanish from sight? The answer is… not really. Suppose we have a really, really big telescope with which we watch one of those distant, high redshift galaxies that is accelerating away from us. Over the course of billions of years, we would see its redshift increase as its speed relative to us increases. (In case you are wondering, it is because in the present-day universe, dark energy dominates over matter; dark energy responds to gravitation as though it was repulsive; so distant parts of the universe accelerate away from each other under the influence of repulsive gravity. In the absence of gravity there would be neither acceleration nor deceleration, just inertial motion.) But what happens when the redshift of a distant galaxy increases? It means that we are watching it in slow motion. And indeed, to us it will appear to slow down, even as it becomes harder and harder to observe, as it both becomes fainter and its light is shifted to the infrared, eventually even to the radio part of the electromagnetic spectrum. And that’s how it will unfold, over the course countless billions of years. That distant galaxy will never appear to reach our cosmological horizon; rather, it will fade from sight as it becomes impossible to observe. But in principle, we could continue observing it, forever and ever, using ever more sensitive, ever more powerful instruments. Incidentally, the same applies when we look at an object falling into a black hole; gravitational redshift near the horizon becomes divergent, so instead of reaching the horizon, an infalling object would appear to slow down and simultaneously become too difficult to observe.  I thank my generous supporters on Patreon. If you like my answers, please consider joining them.

No but it is possible that ‘we’ will see that phenomenon within the next 100 years by specifically programming orbital telescopes ( as one of their programs) to look for extremely redshifted , faint Galaxies and map them , and over a large time span , a few might ‘disappear’ as the light column ends from that particular source from our viewpoint. The phenomenon could also be from dust clouds which interceded , but I think it will eventually be observed with more sensitive telescopes and computer mapping. IF it does occur in the above way , it will prove that this is a definite and real phenomenon , and not just a theoretical idea, obviously red shift occurs , but so far no one has ever seen an entire Galaxy ‘ wink out ‘ from the ‘observable Universe’. Will they get a Nobel Prize for this ‘proof ‘ ? Probably .

No, we haven't directly observed it, but it's entirely possible. In fact, cosmologists believe that as the universe continues to expand and the billions of years pass, the galaxies and other objects at the edge of the observable universe will gradually pass beyond it and become invisible to our view. The universe will become an increasingly sparse place, and as the galaxies we can still see run out of fuel and die, an increasingly dark place. Eventually, there will be nothing left except the occasional white dwarf and neutron star.

No, and that cannot happen. The edge of the observable universe is called the particle horizon. Horizons are one way. Things can enter our observable universe, but not leave. Things near the horizon can redshift a lot, but are in principle always observable. The distance to the particle horizon always increases, whether or not the universe accelerates or decelerates.

Almost every galaxy that we have ever observed outside our local group is moving away from us. Moving closer to the “border” of the observable universe, redshifting. But to see a galaxy fading out of range we have had too little time of observations. Chances that we have seen a galaxy that is moving out of observable range today is very close to zero.

This isn’t possible, as the “observable universe” is expanding by the objects that are at the limit. An object within can’t “move beyond” that, and if it did, it would become the edge of the observable universe.
